awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Ultra-low Power Chemical Vapor Nano-sensor
awd_abstract_narration:
There are numerous areas where air quality or gas composition can enhance the quality of life and safety.  These areas include health and safety (such as detection of methane during mining), medical (breath diagnosis), law enforcement (such as detection of illicit drugs), and vehicle safety (such as checking for alcohol and drugs for safe driving).  Current technology meets some of the needs but is expensive, bulky and power hungry. This project proposes a miniature, ultra-low power, sensitive, microbridge thermal conductivity based gas sensor that uses less than 50 microwatts of power.  In addition, the reproducibility and stability of the sensor are excellent achieving over 30 billion measurements before failure.

The key advantages of the proposed sensors are their ultra-low power consumption and the lack of need for recalibration in the field. This results in substantial cost savings since most chemical sensors require calibrations at given time intervals as well as frequent changes in the battery power. As the sensor is conductimetric, the instrumentation for measurement is very straight forward. The team has investigated methods for minimizing noise and improving stability of the data with pulsed operation. The team has also investigated transient measurements for which the response time is recorded as a function of the gas composition.

por.por_cntn:
Ultra-low power thermal conductivity sensors combined with a MEMS GC system will be a revolutionary technology for portable chemcial vapor analysis with widespread applications in precision agricutlure. We are team 369 and after verifying the market for this technology via meetings and talkiing with over ninety companies and prospective custometers, we formed a company: AnovaTech in December 2014. The first product of the company is a chemical vapor sensor system. This small and light weight sensor is particuarly important for the early detection of a pest or fungal infection on crops. It is also a key technology for the evaluation of food quality and freshness, a growing area of need for improved quality control. Based upon I-corps customer discovery, we made improvements in sensor performance and demonstrated the integrated system for the detection of volatile compounds from Armillaria fungus. During I-Corps we learned tha fungus infection of plants cost the agricultural industry billions of dollars in losses every year. This work has been published in several journal papers, including Journal of Solid State Science and Technology, Micromachines Journal and the Nature Journal of Microsystems and Nanoengineering. In addition, we presented our company capabilities at teh Venture Lab Technology Show Case in Atlanta in the Spring 2015
